Welcome to b2c-crm-sync! Visit Github for the Latest Docs

Congratulations on getting b2c-crm-sync setup in your Salesforce environment! For the latest news, demos, documentation, and issues -- please visit our home on Github. We update the repository, issues, and documentation regularly.


Remember to Complete Your Setup

If you're read our ReadMe document in GitHub, you know that just being able to launch b2c-crm-sync doesn't mean that your configuration is complete. Please ensure that you've completed the following steps as outlined in our setup documentation:


  • Complete the activation and configuration of the B2C Commerce Duplicate Rules used to progressively resolve customer profiles. The ReadMe include instructions for Accounts / Contacts and PersonAccounts.
  • Configure your B2C Instance. A B2C Instance represents a B2C Commerce environment (a sandbox or production instance) that will integrate with this Salesforce Org. Configuring the B2C Instance includes populating this org with the B2C CustomerLists and Sites B2C Commerce customers interact with. These definitions are used to drive the profile resolution and synchronization use cases.

If you've completed these steps, don't forget to validate your installation using the Apex Unit Tests included with b2c-crm-sync and the multi-cloud unit tests that automate exercising these integrated environments in a headless manner.


Deploy Assisted Shopping (Order On Behalf Of)

b2c-crm-sync also includes an extended use-case powered by B2C Commerce: Assisted Shopping (also known as Order on Behalf Of). Use these instructions to configure your Salesforce environment to support this use case.


This is a great example of how you can extend b2c-crm-sync to enable integrated customer experiences. Assisted Shopping leverages the foundational components of b2c-crm-sync to enable this use-case.


Step 1

Create a Named Credential for agents to use to authenticate. This will be on a per-user basis, and each agent will have to set their username and password by clicking on the Profile Image (in the upper right).


  • From the Settings menu, select Authentication Settings for External Systems.
  • Create a New Authentication Credential to allow the agent to connect to B2C Commerce.
  • Select the OOBO Named Credential (it should be pre-defined as part of the b2c-crm-sync deployment).
  • Specify the password that will be used to authenticate the against the B2C Commerce environment.
  • Remember passwords are in the format {password or webKey}:{clientSecret}.


Step 2

Configure each Site that will support Assisted Shopping. The configuration should include enabling the active flag for each storefront, updating the storefront Url, and specifying the NamedCredential used to access B2C Commerce.


  • The active flag on a site is used to manage whether it can be leveraged for integration. Ensure sites are active for Assisted Shopping.
  • The storefront Url represents the customer-facing url used to access the storefront. This is different from the internal environment url used to access Business Manager.
  • Specify the OOBO Named Credential's Developer Name. You can use the Configuration Integration Quick Action to do this.
  • If you want to support Assisted Shopping for Anonymous B2C Commerce Customers, update the OOBO Customer Number and OOBO CustomerID to point to the B2C Commerce Customer Profile all anonymous orders should be anchored to.


Step 3

Configure the Salesforce Platform to view the B2C Commerce storefront as a trusted site. As the authentication and site-forwarding are managed through APIs, Salesforce must view the B2C Commerce environments as trusted.


  • Create entries in CSP Trusted Sites to point to the B2C Commerce storefront url and Business Manager url (these should be two separate records). Configure each site entry to Allow site for connect-src (check this checkbox).
  • Include an entry in Remote Sites to point to the B2C Commerce storefront url and Business Manager url.

Lastly, configure the OCAPI permissions in your B2C Instances to include the Salesforce domains of your org as allowed origins. This reciprocates the trust relationship and constrains access to B2C Commerce APIs.


Step 4

Confirm that the Order on Behalf of Quick Action is available on the  B2C Contact Record Page Layout. Launching the QuickAction will walk the user through a brief flow that leads to creating the appropriate Assisted Shopping experience.
